subject: Re: [junit] Simple JUnit with Annotations not working
msgSnippet: ant test -Dtest.class.name=AnnotationsTest.   When I changed the code as follows , there are two tests that got run successfully. I now have to extend
messageBody:
ant test -Dtest.class.name=AnnotationsTest.
 
When I changed the code as follows , there are two tests that got run successfully. I now have to extend TestCase and name methods starting with test. That was not my intention. I want to use annotations.

import org.junit.Test;
import static org.junit.Assert.* ;
import junit.framework.TestCase;
public class AnnotationsTest extends TestCase{
    @Test 
    public void testAddition() { 
        assertEquals(12, 7+5); 
    } 
     
    @Test 
    public void testSubtraction() { 
        assertEquals(9, 12 -3); 
    } 
}

--- On Tue, 6/2/09, David Saff <david@...> wrote:


From: David Saff <david@...>
Subject: Re: [junit] Simple JUnit with Annotations not working
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Date: Tuesday, June 2, 2009, 1:11 PM








Surikoya,

Sounds frustrating. How are you running the test?

David Saff

On Tue, Jun 2, 2009 at 3:50 PM, surikoya <surikoya@yahoo. com> wrote:
> I am trying the new annotations feature of JUnit4.
>
> Here is the program I am working with. I am using ant 1.6.5 and copied junit-4.6-RC1. jar to my <ant_home>/lib directory and put it in the classpath too. When I run the test I get a message which says "No Tests found in AnnotationsTest" . Did I miss something basic?
>
> import org.junit.Test;
> import static org.junit.Assert. * ;
>
>
> public class AnnotationsTest {
>
>    @Test
>    public void addition() {
>        assertEquals( 12, 7+5);
>    }
